title: Election Commission and Electoral Process in India

information.title: Election Commission
information.description: The Election Commission of India is an autonomous constitutional authority responsible for administering election processes in India. It was established in 1950 under Article 324 of the Constitution.

information.title: Composition
information.description: The Election Commission consists of one Chief Election Commissioner and two Election Commissioners. They are appointed by the President of India and have a tenure of six years or up to the age of 65 years, whichever is earlier.

information.title: Functions
information.description: The Election Commission is responsible for conducting elections to the Parliament, State Legislatures, and offices of the President and Vice-President. It also decides on matters related to recognition of political parties and allotment of election symbols.

information.title: Electoral Process
information.description: The electoral process in India involves several steps including delimitation of constituencies, voter registration, nomination of candidates, campaigning, voting, and counting of votes. The first-past-the-post system is used for most elections.

information.title: Model Code of Conduct
information.description: The Model Code of Conduct is a set of guidelines issued by the Election Commission to regulate political parties and candidates during elections. It comes into force as soon as the election schedule is announced.

information.title: Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs)
information.description: India uses Electronic Voting Machines (EVMs) for casting votes. These were first introduced in 1982 and have been used nationwide since 2004. The use of EVMs has significantly reduced the time taken for vote counting and declaration of results.
